questions.qText: The experimental data for the reaction \(2A + B_{2} \longrightarrow 2AB\) are as follows. Write probable rate expression. \[\begin{array}{ccc} [A] & [B_{2}] & \text{Rate} \\ {[\mathrm{mol\,L^{-1}}]} & {[\mathrm{mol\,L^{-1}}]} & {[\mathrm{mol\,L^{-1}\,s^{-1}}]} \\ 0.50 & 0.50 & \left(1.6\times 10^{-4}\right) \\ 0.50 & 1.00 & \left(3.2\times 10^{-4}\right) \\ 1.00 & 1.00 & \left(3.2\times 10^{-4}\right) \end{array}\] (Options are made-up distractors; one is correct.)

Calculate order of reaction \(A + B \longrightarrow \text{Product}\), w.r.t. \(A\) from the following data: \[\begin{array}{ccc} [A] & [B] & \text{Rate} \\ \text{(Rate in }\times 10^{-5}\,\mathrm{mol\,L^{-1}\,s^{-1}}\text{)} \\ (i) & 0.01 & 0.010 & 5.0 \\ (ii) & 0.01 & 0.015 & 5.0 \\ (iii) & 0.02 & 0.010 & 14.1 \end{array}\]

Calculate order of reaction \(A + B \longrightarrow \text{Product}\), w.r.t. \(B\) from the following data: \[\begin{array}{ccc} [A] & [B] & \text{Rate} \\ \text{(Rate in }\times 10^{-5}\,\mathrm{mol\,L^{-1}\,s^{-1}}\text{)} \\ (i) & 0.01 & 0.010 & 5.0 \\ (ii) & 0.01 & 0.015 & 5.0 \\ (iii) & 0.02 & 0.010 & 14.1 \end{array}\]

The virus prepared in a chemical bath shows an inactivation process obeying first order kinetics. Calculate the rate constant for the viral inactivation if initially 1.5% of the virus is inactivated per minute.
The virus prepared in a chemical bath shows an inactivation process obeying first order kinetics. Calculate the time required for 50% inactivation.
The virus prepared in a chemical bath shows an inactivation process obeying first order kinetics. Calculate the time required for 80% inactivation.
For a first order reaction, the time required for 99.9% decomposition of the reaction is how many times the time required for half of the reaction?
The time required for 20% completion for a first order reaction is 10 minutes. Calculate the specific reaction rate.
The time required for 20% completion for a first order reaction is 10 minutes. Calculate the time required for 75% completion.
The half life for a first order reaction \(A \longrightarrow \text{Product}\) is 10 minutes. What percent of \(A\) remains after 1 hour?

The reaction \(\mathrm{SO_{2}Cl_{2} \rightarrow SO_{2} + Cl_{2}}\) obeys first order kinetics with rate constant \(3.2\times 10^{-5}\,\mathrm{s^{-1}}\) at 320 \(^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). What percent of \(\mathrm{SO_{2}Cl_{2}}\) will be decomposed on heating the gas for 90 minutes?
Thermal decomposition of a compound is first order. If 50% of the sample decomposes in 120 minutes, how long will it take for 90% of the compound to decompose?

A reaction, \(2A \longrightarrow \text{Products}\); has a rate constant \(3.5\times 10^{-4}\,\mathrm{mol^{-1}\,L\,s^{-1}}\). Find the time required for the concentration of \(A\) to change from \(0.26\,\mathrm{M}\) to \(0.011\,\mathrm{M}\). (Hint: unit of \(k\) suggests second order.)

The rate constant for the decomposition of ozone following second order kinetics is \(5\times 10^{-3}\,\mathrm{L\,mol^{-1}\,s^{-1}}\) at a certain temperature. What is the rate of reaction if the concentration of ozone is \(2\times 10^{-8}\,\mathrm{mol\,L^{-1}}\)?

The rate constant for the decomposition of ozone (following second order kinetics) is \(5\times10^{-3}\) L mol^-1 s^-1 at a certain temperature. What is the rate of reaction if the concentration of ozone is \(2\times10^{-8}\) mol L^-1? Calculate the rate in terms of number of molecules decomposed per mL per minute.
A reaction obeying second order in \(A\) is 50% complete after 450 minutes. If \([A]_0 = 1.35\,\mathrm{M}\), calculate its rate constant.
Decomposition of a substance \(A\) follows first order kinetics. Starting initially with \([A] = 2.0\,\mathrm{M}\) and after 200 minutes \([A] = 0.25\,\mathrm{M}\), calculate half life period.
Decomposition of a substance \(A\) follows first order kinetics. Starting initially with \([A] = 2.0\,\mathrm{M}\) and after 200 minutes \([A] = 0.25\,\mathrm{M}\), calculate rate constant.

For a homogeneous gaseous reaction, \(A \longrightarrow B + C + D\); the initial pressure was \(P_0\) while pressure after time \(t\) was \(P\). Derive an expression for rate constant \(K\) in terms of \(P_0\), \(P\) and \(t\). Assume first order reaction. (Options are made-up distractors; one is correct.)
A second order reaction with two reactants is started with 0.1 M concentration of each. After 30 minutes, 10% has reacted. Calculate the specific reaction rate.
A second order reaction with two reactants is started with 0.1 M concentration of each. After 30 minutes, 10% has reacted. Calculate the half-life period.
A substance is reduced to one-third of its original concentration in 100 minutes. Calculate the time in which it will be reduced to one-ninth of its original value. Assume first order kinetics.

From the following data for the decomposition of diazobenzene chloride, show that the reaction is first order and report the rate constant. \\[\text{Time (min): }20, 50, 70, \infty;\; \text{Vol. of }N_2(\mathrm{mL}):10, 25, 33, 162\]

The specific rate constant of the decomposition of \(\ce{N2O5}\) is \(0.008\,\mathrm{min^{-1}}\). The volume of \(\ce{O2}\) collected after 20 minutes is 16 mL. Find the volume that would be collected at the end of reaction. \(\ce{NO2}\) formed is dissolved in \(\ce{CCl4}\).

Dimethyl ether gaseous-phase decomposition is \(\ce{CH3OCH3 -> CH4 + H2 + CO}\) at 750 K having rate constant \(6.72 \times 10^{-3}\,\mathrm{min^{-1}}\). Calculate the time in which initial pressure of 400 mm in a closed container becomes 750 mm.

A solution of \(\ce{N2O5}\) in \(\ce{CCl4}\) at 45\,^{\circ}\mathrm{C} produces 5.02 mL of \(\ce{O2}\) in 1198 s and 9.58 mL \(\ce{O2}\) after a long time. Calculate the rate constant assuming first order for the reaction \(\ce{N2O5 -> N2O4 + 1/2 O2}\).

For the decomposition of \(\ce{N2O5}\), the rate constant is \(6.2 \times 10^{-4}\,\mathrm{s^{-1}}\) at 45\,^{\circ}\mathrm{C}. It begins with one mole of \(\ce{N2O5}\) in a litre flask. How long would it take for 20% of \(\ce{N2O5}\) to decompose?

For the decomposition of \(\ce{N2O5}\), the rate constant is \(6.2 \times 10^{-4}\,\mathrm{s^{-1}}\) at 45\,^{\circ}\mathrm{C}. It begins with one mole of \(\ce{N2O5}\) in a litre flask. How long would it take for 50% of \(\ce{N2O5}\) to decompose?

The decomposition of \(\ce{Cl2O7}\) at 400 K in the gaseous phase to \(\ce{Cl2}\) and \(\ce{O2}\) is a first-order reaction. After 55 s at 400 K, the pressure of the reaction mixture increases from 0.62 atm to 1.88 atm. Calculate the rate constant.

The decomposition of \(\ce{Cl2O7}\) at 400 K in the gaseous phase to \(\ce{Cl2}\) and \(\ce{O2}\) is first order. After 55 s at 400 K, the pressure increases from 0.62 atm to 1.88 atm. Calculate the pressure after 100 s.

The vapour-phase decomposition of ethylene oxide into methane and CO at 414.5\,^{\circ}\mathrm{C} is given below. Calculate \(k\) for a first-order reaction: Time (min): 0, 5, 7, 12, 18; Pressure (mm Hg): 116.51, 122.72, 125.72, 133.23, 141.37.

In the vapour-phase decomposition of ethylene oxide, \(\ce{C2H4O -> CH4 + CO}\) at 414.5\,^{\circ}\mathrm{C}, the initial pressure and the pressure after 5 minutes were 116.51 mm Hg and 122.56 mm Hg respectively. If the reaction follows first-order kinetics, what must be the pressure after 12 minutes?

Decomposition of diazobenzene chloride was followed at constant temperature by measuring the volume of \(\ce{N2}\) evolved at definite intervals of time. Calculate the order of reaction. \\[\text{Time (min): }0, 2.0, 5.5, 7.0, \infty;\; V_{N_2}(\mathrm{mL}): 0, 10, 25, 35, 163\]

Decomposition of diazobenzene chloride was followed at constant temperature by measuring the volume of \(\ce{N2}\) evolved at definite intervals of time. Calculate the rate constant. \\[\text{Time (min): }0, 2.0, 5.5, 7.0, \infty;\; V_{N_2}(\mathrm{mL}): 0, 10, 25, 35, 163\]

Calculate the partial pressure of \(\ce{(CH3)2N2}\) when azomethane decomposes at an initial pressure of 200 mm for 30 minutes according to \(\ce{(CH3)2N2 -> C2H6 + N2}\). The rate constant is \(2.5 \times 10^{-4}\,\mathrm{s^{-1}}\).

Calculate the partial pressure of \(\ce{C2H6}\) when azomethane decomposes at an initial pressure of 200 mm for 30 minutes according to \(\ce{(CH3)2N2 -> C2H6 + N2}\). The rate constant is \(2.5 \times 10^{-4}\,\mathrm{s^{-1}}\).

Calculate the partial pressure of \(\ce{N2}\) when azomethane decomposes at an initial pressure of 200 mm for 30 minutes according to \(\ce{(CH3)2N2 -> C2H6 + N2}\). The rate constant is \(2.5 \times 10^{-4}\,\mathrm{s^{-1}}\).

The thermal decomposition of azoisopropane to hexane and nitrogen follows first order kinetics. If \(P_i\) is the initial pressure of the reactant and \(P\) is the total pressure after reaction, derive an expression for the rate constant \(K\) in terms of \(P_i\), \(P\), and \(t\). (Options are made-up distractors; one is correct.)

The thermal decomposition of \(\ce{N2O5}\) occurs in the following steps: Step I \(\ce{N2O5 ->[Slow] NO2 + NO3}\); Step II \(\ce{NO3 + NO2 ->[Fast] N2O5}\). Find the rate-determining step and the rate law. (Options are made-up distractors; one is correct.)
The reaction \(\ce{H2 + I2 -> 2HI}\) is elementary. What is the rate law?
Which one of the following will have the largest half-life period at the same temperature?
The hydrolysis of an ester in acid medium is an example of what order?
The energy difference between reactants and activated complex is called what?
In a reaction mechanism, the slowest step is known as what?
If a reaction has a half-life independent of initial concentration, the reaction must be of which order?
The decomposition of hydrogen peroxide in aqueous solution follows first-order kinetics. If its rate constant is \(0.04\,\mathrm{min^{-1}}\), what fraction decomposes in 25 min?
A radioactive isotope decays with a half-life of 30 min. What fraction of the isotope remains after 2 h?
If the rate constant doubles when temperature rises by 10 K, what is the activation energy approximately (take \(R = 8.314\,\mathrm{J\,mol^{-1}\,K^{-1}}\))?
For a first-order reaction, if \(k = 1.15 \times 10^{-3}\,\mathrm{s^{-1}}\), what is the half-life?
For a zero-order reaction, the half-life \(t_{1/2} = \dfrac{[A]_0}{2k}\). If the initial concentration is doubled, what happens to the half-life?
If the half-life of a first-order reaction is 2 h, how long will it take for 75\% completion?
At 400\,^{\circ}\mathrm{C}, decomposition of phosphine (\(\ce{PH3}\)) follows first-order kinetics. If 75\% decomposes in 50 s, find the rate constant.
For the reaction \(\ce{2HI -> H2 + I2}\), the rate doubles when temperature increases from 298 K to 308 K. Find \(E_a\) using Arrhenius relation.
In a bimolecular reaction, doubling both reactant concentrations increases the rate four times. What is the overall order?
For the first-order reaction, \(k = \dfrac{2.303}{t} \log_{10}\left(\dfrac{a}{a - x}\right)\). If \(a = 0.1\,\mathrm{M}\) and after 50 min \(x = 0.075\,\mathrm{M}\), find \(k\).
For a second-order reaction \(2A \rightarrow \text{Products}\), rate law is \(r = k[A]^2\). If \(t_{1/2} = \dfrac{1}{k[A]_0}\), what happens to \(t_{1/2}\) when \([A]_0\) doubles?
If rate constant \(k\) has units of \(\mathrm{mol^{-1}\,L\,s^{-1}}\), what is the order of reaction?
A first-order reaction is 40\% complete in 20 min. Calculate its half-life.
For a first-order reaction, when concentration decreases from \(0.5\,\mathrm{M}\) to \(0.125\,\mathrm{M}\) in 60 min, find \(k\).
The reaction \(\ce{2NO + Cl2 -> 2NOCl}\) has rate law \(r = k[NO]^2[Cl2]\). What happens to the rate if \([NO]\) doubles and \([Cl2]\) triples?
A first-order reaction has \(k = 1.0\times10^{-3}\,\mathrm{s^{-1}}\). In what time will 90\% react?
The temperature coefficient of a reaction is 2.5. If rate at 300 K is \(1.2\times10^{-3}\), find the rate at 330 K.
For a radioactive decay process, activity drops to \(\tfrac{1}{16}\) in 24 days. Find its half-life.
Which graph correctly represents a zero-order reaction?
